title: Billy Porter talks toughest ‘Pose’ acting scenes, and praises Jonathan Van Ness for HIV disclosure
text:
Billy Porter had himself a night on Sunday while making Emmy history.

The “Pose” star wrote his name in the record books when he became the first openly gay black man to win lead actor in a drama category.

Already holding a Tony and a Grammy, he's now just one Oscar away from the elusive EGOT.

EMMYS 2019: 'GAME OF THRONES,' FLEABAG,' WIN BIG, BILLY PORTER MAKES HISTORY

Porter spoke with Fox News on the Emmys purple carpet and opened up about just how much the show has changed his life in just two seasons.

“You know, I always felt – I came out in the '80s, right. Black, gay, [the] '80s. We went straight to the front lines to fight for our lives,” Porter began. “The 'T' in LGBTQ, for me, was unconsciously absent from my knowledge or understanding for real. This show and these ladies and these trans men on this show has taught me what true authenticity really looks like. And we get to teach the world what that looks like with our show. And it is the biggest gift and blessing that any artist could ever hope or dream for.”

Porter, who celebrated the big 5-0 just two days ago, opened up about the most difficult aspect of working on the trailblazing series and said the show’s somber tone actually took a toll on him.

BILLY PORTER DEFENDS OSCARS TUXEDO GOWN AFTER BACKLASH

“Two difficult things that were hard for me. The subject matter – you know, the AIDS crisis part of it can be really dark. Sometimes that can be really dark. Sometimes that's hard to live inside of,” said Porter, adding that Season 2 was easier to perform due in part to a more encouraging storyline.

“The fun version of that is this past season. They wrote Pray Tell not being able to walk in heels. That was difficult to act,” Porter explained with hysterical amusement. “And then the sex scene – I had never had a love scene before and that was like, 'Ahhh! They're making me naked at 49!'”

After accepting his Emmy honor, the performer spoke to reporters backstage in the press room and praised “Queer Eye” star Jonathan Van Ness for revealing his HIV-positive status and shedding new light on the discussion to usher change.

SEE ALL THE WINNERS OF THE 2019 EMMYS

“We need to take the stigma away from it, influence people like Jonathan who allow for the stigma to be taken away,” said Porter. “It's not HIV porn, you know. It's not all sadness, just like our show. You know, the point of our show is aspirational.”

“You're watching people in the depths of the worst of circumstances – the most dire of circumstances, choose life anyway. We all choose life anyway. That's what it's about. I'm happy for Jonathan and I'm happy for the world.”
description: Billy Porter certainly had himself a night on Sunday while making Emmy history.
authors: Julius Is An La Entertainment Reporter For Fox News.
